lessons.en: ðŸ“š Welcome to Grammar for Class 9-10! This section covers advanced grammar concepts for SSC/HSC preparation. Read each lesson carefully, practice with examples, and test yourself. Let's make English easy!

Review basic parts of speech: Noun (person, place, thing), Pronoun (replaces noun), Verb (action/state), Adjective (describes noun), Adverb (modifies verb/adjective/adverb), Preposition (shows relation), Conjunction (connects words/clauses), Interjection (emotion).

Advanced Nouns: Abstract nouns (ideas: freedom, happiness, courage), Collective nouns (group: team, committee, parliament), Compound nouns (two words: classroom, toothbrush, rickshaw-puller), Countable vs. Uncountable (books vs. water, mangoes vs. rice).
Advanced Pronouns: Relative pronouns (who, which, that) connect clauses. Reflexive pronouns (myself, himself) refer back. Reciprocal pronouns (each other, one another) show mutual action.

Advanced Verbs: Transitive verbs take objects (She reads books). Intransitive verbs don't (He sleeps). Finite verbs show tense (runs, ran). Non-finite verbs: infinitive (to run), gerund (running), participle (running, run).
Advanced Adjectives: Demonstrative (this, that, these, those), Distributive (each, every, either, neither), Interrogative (which, what, whose), Possessive (my, your, his, her, its, our, their).
Advanced Adverbs: Manner (quickly, carefully), Place (here, there, everywhere), Time (now, yesterday, soon), Frequency (always, often, never), Degree (very, too, quite, rather).

Conjunctions: Coordinating (and, but, or, nor, for, so, yet) join equal parts. Subordinating (because, although, if, when, since) introduce dependent clauses. Correlative (either...or, neither...nor, not only...but also) work in pairs.
Interjections express sudden emotion: Oh! (surprise), Alas! (sorrow), Hurray! (joy), Wow! (amazement), Ouch! (pain). Use exclamation marks or commas.
Determiners specify nouns: Articles (a, an, the), Demonstratives (this, that), Quantifiers (some, many, few), Numbers (one, two, first). Position: Determiner + Adjective + Noun.
Identifying parts of speech in context: The same word can be different parts. Fast: She runs fast (adverb). She is fast (adjective). She fasts (verb). Context determines the part of speech.

lessons.en: Prepositions link nouns with time, place, and other details. Learn common collocations such as 'in the morning', 'on the weekend', 'at school', and 'from Dhaka to Chittagong'.

Use 'look forward to', 'depend on', and 'take care of' to pair verbs with prepositions; changing the preposition often changes the meaning. Example: 'look forward to' (anticipate) vs. 'look into' (investigate).
Pair adjectives with prepositions: excited about, proud of, afraid of, tired from, similar to. These combinations sound natural in speech and writing.
Prepositions of time like 'during', 'since', 'for', and 'by' help you describe deadlines and durations. 'We studied for two hours' vs. 'We finished by noon'.
Prepositions of movement: go to school, walk through the market, run towards the gate, travel by train. Practice connecting verbs of motion with correct prepositions for precise meaning.

lessons.en:
Noun: Advanced classification and usage.
Abstract nouns: democracy, poverty, courage, honesty, loyalty
Collective nouns: government, committee, jury, orchestra, audience, congregation
Mass nouns: information, equipment, furniture, luggage, baggage, machinery

Pronoun: Expanded understanding and usage.
Relative pronouns: who (subject), whom (object), whose (possessive), which (things), that (people/things)
Compound relative pronouns: whoever, whomever, whatever, whichever
Reflexive usage: emphasizing and reflexive forms of pronouns

Verb: Tense and aspect understanding.
Present tense: Simple (read), Continuous (is reading), Perfect (has read), Perfect Continuous (has been reading)
Past tense: Simple (read), Continuous (was reading), Perfect (had read), Perfect Continuous (had been reading)
Future tense: Simple (will read), Continuous (will be reading), Perfect (will have read), Perfect Continuous (will have been reading)

Adjective: Advanced forms and functions.
Comparative: This book is more interesting than that one.
Superlative: This is the most interesting book I have ever read.
Absolute adjectives: perfect, unique, complete (cannot be compared)
Participial adjectives: fascinating, broken, intriguing, disappointed

Adverb: Position and function.
Initial position: Unfortunately, he didn't attend the meeting.
Mid position: He unfortunately didn't attend the meeting.
Final position: He didn't attend the meeting, unfortunately.
Adverbs modifying adjectives: extremely difficult, quite beautiful, rather complex
Adverbs modifying adverbs: very slowly, quite rapidly, extremely carefully

Preposition: Complex usage and functions.
Phrases: by accident, in fact, on purpose, at random
Temporal prepositions: during, throughout, within, pending
Causal prepositions: because of, due to, as a result of, in view of

Conjunction: Advanced conjunction usage.
Adverbial conjunctions: moreover, furthermore, however, nevertheless, instead, meanwhile
Parallel structures: Both...and, either...or, neither...nor maintain equal weight
Subordinate conjunctions for cause-effect: because, since, as, inasmuch as
Subordinate conjunctions for contrast: although, though, while, whereas

Determiners and Modifiers: Words that determine or modify nouns.
Demonstrative determiners: this book, that idea, these concepts, those principles
Possessive determiners: my work, your opinion, his analysis, her conclusion
Quantifying determiners: some people, any question, all answers, several topics, much detail, many examples

Whoever applies first will definitely receive the scholarship. (Whoever - compound relative pronoun, applies - verb, first - adverb, will receive - future tense verb, scholarship - noun)

The equipment has been thoroughly examined by our specialists. (The - article, equipment - mass noun, has been examined - present perfect passive, thoroughly - adverb, by - preposition, our - possessive determiner, specialists - noun)

Although the project was challenging, the team worked exceptionally well together. (Although - subordinating conjunction, project - noun, was - verb, challenging - participle, team - collective noun, worked - verb, exceptionally - adverb modifying adverb, well - adverb)

The proposal, which was innovative yet practical, impressed both the investors and the stakeholders. (The - article, proposal - noun, which - relative pronoun, was - verb, innovative, practical - adjectives, impressed - verb, both...and - correlative conjunctions, investors, stakeholders - nouns)

He has been working consistently on the research since the project commenced. (He - pronoun, has been working - present perfect continuous tense, consistently - adverb, on - preposition, research - noun, since - subordinating conjunction, project - noun, commenced - verb)

Regrettably, most of the historical documentation was either lost or destroyed. (Regrettably - adverb in initial position, most - quantifying determiner, historical - adjective, documentation - noun, was - verb, either...or - correlative conjunction, lost, destroyed - adjectives)

Moreover, several theories suggest that consciousness might ultimately remain unexplainable. (Moreover - adverbial conjunction, several - quantifying determiner, theories - noun, suggest - verb, consciousness - abstract noun, might remain - modal verb, unexplainable - adjective)

lessons.en:
Phrase: A group of words without a subject + verb pair. Think of it like a part of a sentence, not a complete thought.
Structure: no complete subjectâ€“verb.
Examples: the happy child, in the morning, very beautiful, quite quickly, at Cox's Bazar, from Dhaka.

Clause: A group of words that has a subject and a verb. This is like a complete thought!
Independent clause: full sentence (She reads books. Bangladesh is beautiful).
Dependent clause: needs another clause (because she likes reading, when the Pohela Boishakh comes, if the rain stops).
ðŸ’¡ Student Tip: If you can say it alone and it makes sense, it's independent!

Simple sentence: one independent clause.
Structure: Subject + Verb (+ Object).
Examples: The students study. Birds sing beautifully. Dhaka is the capital.
ðŸ’¡ This is the easiest type - just one complete thought!

Compound sentence: two independent clauses joined by and/but/or/nor/yet/so.
Structure: Clause 1 + , + conjunction + Clause 2.
Example: She studied hard, and she passed the SSC exam.
Example: Rahim went to Chittagong, but Karim stayed in Dhaka.
ðŸ’¡ Remember FANBOYS: For, And, Nor, But, Or, Yet, So

Complex sentence: one independent clause + one dependent clause (because, if, when, although, since, unless, while, before, after).
Structure: Dependent + , + Independent OR Independent + Dependent.
Example: Because she studied hard, she passed the exam.
Example: When it rains in Bangladesh, the roads become muddy.
ðŸ’¡ Dependent clauses start with: because, if, when, although, since, unless, while, before, after

Compound-complex sentence: two independent clauses + at least one dependent clause. This is the most advanced type!
Structure: Dependent + Independent + conjunction + Independent.
Example: Because she studied hard, she passed the exam, and her parents were proud.
Example: When Pohela Boishakh comes, we celebrate, and everyone wears traditional clothes.
ðŸ’¡ Student tip for SSC/HSC: Write two short sentences, then join them with 'and' or 'but'. Add 'because/if/when' to show reason or time. Practice makes perfect!

Everyday practice: Make 2â€“3 short sentences about your day in Bangladesh, then combine them using because/when/if. Keep each sentence clear and short. Example: I went to school. I met my friend. â†’ I went to school, and I met my friend.

SIMPLE SENTENCE: The students study grammar in Dhaka schools.
Subject: The students | Verb: study | One independent clause.

SIMPLE SENTENCE: She played cricket and sang songs at the school program.
Subject: She | Verbs: played, sang (compound verb) | One independent clause.

COMPOUND SENTENCE: I love reading Bengali poetry, and my sister loves dancing.
Clause 1: I love reading Bengali poetry | Clause 2: my sister loves dancing | Connected with 'and'.

COMPOUND SENTENCE: The cricket match ended, but the fans in Dhaka continued cheering.
Clause 1: The cricket match ended | Clause 2: the fans in Dhaka continued cheering | Connected with 'but'.

COMPLEX SENTENCE: Because the weather was bad in Chittagong, the match was postponed.
Dependent clause: Because the weather was bad in Chittagong | Independent clause: the match was postponed.

COMPLEX SENTENCE: She will attend the Pohela Boishakh festival if she finishes her homework.
Independent clause: She will attend the Pohela Boishakh festival | Dependent clause: if she finishes her homework.

COMPOUND-COMPLEX: When the school bell rang, the students left the class, and the teacher went to the staff room.
Dependent: When the school bell rang | Independent 1: the students left the class | Independent 2: the teacher went to the staff room.

lessons.en: Review the basics: 'a' or 'an' for one nonspecific item (a book, an umbrella) and 'the' for something someone already knows about (the book we read yesterday).
Use 'the' for unique things or well-known places: the sun, the President, the Prime Minister, the Bay of Bengal.
Zero article (no 'a' or 'the') works with plural general ideas (Students love festivals) and most country names (Bangladesh is beautiful) or meals (We ate lunch).
Special cases: Use 'the' with rivers, oceans, mountain ranges, newspapers, and some countries (the Nile, the Pacific, the Himalayas, the Daily Star, the United Kingdom).
Reminder for learners: Think of your day at school or the market. If you talk about a new item you saw, say 'a'. When you mention the same item again or a known place, use 'the'.
Decide between 'a' and 'an' by sound: use 'an' before vowel sounds (an apple, an hour, an honour) and 'a' before consonant sounds even if the first letter is a vowel (a university, a one-time event).

Use 'a/an' with singular, countable nouns when you introduce them (a book, an umbrella), but drop the article for plural countables or uncountables when speaking generally (Books are expensive, Water is precious). Use 'some' for unspecified plural/uncountable references.
Choose 'the' before superlatives, ordinals, institutions, and when you talk about what everybody knows (the best student, the first prize, the university, the older brother).

Remember that proper nouns usually skip the article unless they refer to groups, rivers, oceans, or are plural (the Himalayas, the Danube, the United States) or include words like 'Republic' or 'Kingdom'.

lessons.en: Continuous tenses show actions in progress. Structure: be + verb-ing.
Simple tenses show routine, facts, or completed actions. Structure: Base verb / V2 / will + base verb.
Simple present: base verb (s/es with he/she/it). Use for habits and facts.
Simple past: V2. Use for completed actions in the past.
Simple future: will + base verb. Use for future actions or decisions.
Present continuous: am/is/are + verb-ing. Use for actions happening now or temporary actions.
Past continuous: was/were + verb-ing. Use for actions in progress at a specific past time.
Future continuous: will be + verb-ing. Use for actions that will be in progress at a future time.
Perfect tenses show completion. Structure: have/has/had + past participle (V3).
Present perfect: has/have + V3. Use for completed actions with result now or life experience.
Past perfect: had + V3. Use for the earlier of two past actions.
Perfect continuous: has/have been + verb-ing or had been + verb-ing to show duration.
Present perfect continuous: has/have been + verb-ing. Use for actions started in the past and continuing now.
Past perfect continuous: had been + verb-ing. Use for actions that continued up to a past time.

Subjectâ€“verb agreement means the verb must match the subject in number (singular/plural). This is a common mistake area in SSC/HSC exams - master this!
ðŸ’¡ Basic Rule: Singular subject = singular verb | Plural subject = plural verb

Singular subjects take singular verbs: He runs to school, Rahim has a book, This mango is sweet. Plural subjects take plural verbs: They run to school, The students have books, These mangoes are sweet.
ðŸ’¡ Tip: If subject is 'one person or thing' â†’ use is/was/has. If 'many' â†’ use are/were/have

Collective nouns (team, committee, family, class, parliament) take a singular verb when the group acts as one; they can take a plural verb when members act separately.
Example: The Bangladesh cricket team is strong. (one unit)
Example: The team are wearing different jerseys. (individual members)

Each/every/either/neither/anyone/someone/everyone are ALWAYS singular: Each Bangladeshi student is talented. Everyone has passed the exam.
ðŸ’¡ Remember: Words with 'one/body/thing' at the end are singular!

Subjects joined by 'and' are usually plural: Rahim and Karim are friends. Dhaka and Chittagong are big cities. But a single unit is singular: Rice and curry is my lunch. Bread and butter is a common snack.
ðŸ’¡ If two things make one item, use singular verb!

Subjects joined by or/nor: the verb agrees with the NEAREST subject: Neither the students nor the teacher is late. Neither the teacher nor the students are late.
ðŸ’¡ Look at the subject closest to the verb!
A number of = plural; the number of = singular. Example: A number of students are absent. The number of students is high.
Nouns that look plural but are singular: news, mathematics, physics. Example: The news is good.
Some nouns are always plural: scissors, trousers, spectacles. They take plural verbs: The scissors are sharp.
With 'there is/are', the verb agrees with the real subject: There is a book. There are many books.
With quantities: A lot of/some of depends on the noun. Some of the water is clean. Some of the students are late.

Sentence Transformation: Converting a sentence from one form to another without changing its meaning. This is very important for SSC/HSC exams!
Types: Affirmative to Negative, Simple to Complex, Complex to Compound, Active to Passive voice, Direct to Indirect speech.

Affirmative to Negative Transformation:
Affirmative: She is honest.
Negative: She is not dishonest.
Affirmative: All Bangladeshi students passed.
Negative: No Bangladeshi student failed.
ðŸ’¡ Student Tip: Use opposite words with 'not' to transform.

Simple Sentence to Complex Sentence:
Simple: Despite the rain in Dhaka, he attended school.
Complex: Although it rained in Dhaka, he attended school.
Simple: After finishing homework, I went to play cricket.
Complex: After I finished homework, I went to play cricket.
ðŸ’¡ Use 'Although', 'Because', 'When', 'If' to make complex sentences.

Simple Sentence to Compound Sentence:
Simple: He ran quickly to catch the bus to Chittagong.
Compound: He ran quickly, and he managed to catch the bus to Chittagong.
Simple: Realizing his mistake, Rahim apologized.
Compound: Rahim realized his mistake, and he apologized.

Using 'too...to' and 'so...that' transformations:
Original: The traffic in Dhaka is too heavy to pass through.
Using 'so': The traffic in Dhaka is so heavy that I cannot pass through it.
Original: She is intelligent enough to solve this SSC problem.
Using 'so': She is so intelligent that she can solve this SSC problem.

Using 'Whoever', 'Whatever', 'Whichever' in transformations:
Simple: Anyone who works hard will succeed.
Complex: Whoever works hard will succeed.
Simple: Do whatever is needed.
Complex: Do whichever thing is needed.

Interrogative transformation: Change statements into questions by inverting the auxiliary or adding do-support.
Statement: You have completed the SSC exam preparation.
Question: Have you completed the SSC exam preparation?
Statement: She likes playing cricket.
Question: Does she like playing cricket?
ðŸ’¡ Remember: When the sentence has must/can/will, simply swap the modal and the subject.

Imperative to polite request: Add a modal and an infinitive to soften commands. This is important in formal writing!
Imperative: Close the door.
Request: Please close the door.
Imperative: Don't leave late.
Request: Kindly do not leave late.
ðŸ’¡ Use 'please', 'kindly' and modals (could, would, can) for polite tone.

Changing affirmative sentences to exclamations and vice versa: Add 'what/how' + subject + verb for exclamatory effect.
Affirmative: The view is beautiful.
Exclamation: What a beautiful view it is!
Affirmative: He ran very fast.
Exclamation: How fast he ran!
Reverse by replacing 'what/how' clauses with simple statements.

lessons.en:
Voice: The relationship between the verb and the subject. This is very important for SSC/HSC exams!
Active Voice: Subject performs the action. (Who did it? - Focus on the doer)
Example: The students cleaned the classroom.
Passive Voice: Subject receives the action. (What happened? - Focus on the action)
Example: The classroom was cleaned by the students.
ðŸ’¡ Student Tip: In passive voice, move the object to the front and use 'by' before the subject!

Active to Passive Voice Transformation:
Active: Subject + Verb + Object
Passive: Object + was/were/is/are + past participle + by + Subject
Example: Rahim writes a letter. â†’ A letter is written by Rahim.
Example: They will build the Padma Bridge. â†’ The Padma Bridge will be built by them.
ðŸ’¡ Remember: Use correct form of 'be' (is/am/are/was/were) + past participle (V3)

Present Tense Active to Passive:
Active: He eats an apple. â†’ Passive: An apple is eaten by him.
Active: They play football. â†’ Passive: Football is played by them.
Active: She teaches English. â†’ Passive: English is taught by her.

Past Tense Active to Passive:
Active: The students wrote an essay. â†’ Passive: An essay was written by the students.
Active: They built the Padma Bridge. â†’ Passive: The Padma Bridge was built by them.
Active: She bought a new saree from Dhaka. â†’ Passive: A new saree was bought by her from Dhaka.
ðŸ’¡ Past tense: use 'was' or 'were' + V3

Future Tense Active to Passive:
Active: He will complete the SSC homework. â†’ Passive: The SSC homework will be completed by him.
Active: She will solve the math problem. â†’ Passive: The math problem will be solved by her.
Active: Bangladesh Cricket Team will win the match. â†’ Passive: The match will be won by Bangladesh Cricket Team.
ðŸ’¡ Future: use 'will be' + V3

When to use Passive Voice (Important for exam writing!):
âœ“ Focus on the action or result (not who did it)
âœ“ When the agent is unknown: The museum was robbed.
âœ“ When the agent is obvious: He was arrested (by police).
âœ“ In formal or scientific writing: The experiment was conducted carefully.
âœ“ When the agent is less important: The school was damaged in the storm.

Perfect tenses in passive: Combine have/has/had + been + past participle to keep the sense of completion without naming the actor.
Example: Active: She has completed the task. â†’ Passive: The task has been completed by her.
Active: They had studied the course. â†’ Passive: The course had been studied by them.

Modal verbs in passive use modal + be + past participle to express possibility, permission, or obligation while keeping the object as the focus.
Example: Active: You can submit the report. â†’ Passive: The report can be submitted by you.
Active: He must deliver the speech. â†’ Passive: The speech must be delivered by him.
Example: Active: They should finish the project. â†’ Passive: The project should be finished by them.

Leave out the agent when it is unknown or irrelevant; include it with 'by' when you must mention the doer.
Example: Active: People admire her talent. â†’ Passive: Her talent is admired (by people).
Use the passive in academic and formal writing to stress the action or outcome rather than the performer.

Narration: The way we report what someone said.
Direct Narration: Uses exact words with quotation marks.
Example: He said, "I am happy."
Indirect Narration: Reports the meaning without exact words.
Example: He said that he was happy.

Rules for converting Direct to Indirect:
1. Remove quotation marks and commas
2. Change pronouns based on the perspective
3. Change tenses (usually one step back)
4. Change adverbs: todayâ†’that day, hereâ†’there, nowâ†’then, yesterdayâ†’the day before
5. Change questions with 'if' or 'whether'
6. Change imperatives with 'to'

Tense Changes in Indirect Speech:
Direct: "I am tired." â†’ Indirect: He said he was tired.
Direct: "I go to school." â†’ Indirect: She said she went to school.
Direct: "I have finished." â†’ Indirect: He said he had finished.
Direct: "I will come." â†’ Indirect: She said she would come.

Question Conversion:
Direct: He asked, "What is your name?"
Indirect: He asked what her name was.
Direct: She asked, "Will you come tomorrow?"
Indirect: She asked if/whether I would come the next day.
Direct: "Where do you live?" â†’ Indirect: He asked where she lived.

Imperative (Command/Request) Conversion:

Direct: "Please help me." â†’ Indirect: He requested me to help him.

Adverb and Pronoun Changes:

Direct: "Come here." â†’ Indirect: He asked me to go there.

lessons.en:
Combining Sentences: Joining two or more simple sentences to make a compound or complex sentence. This skill is essential for good writing in SSC/HSC exams!
Goals: Reduce repetition, improve flow, show relationships between ideas, make writing more concise and mature.

Combining with coordinating conjunctions (and, but, or, nor, yet, so):
Simple: She is intelligent. She is hardworking.
Combined: She is intelligent and hardworking.
Simple: Rahim wanted to go to Cox's Bazar. He had no money.
Combined: Rahim wanted to go to Cox's Bazar, but he had no money.
ðŸ’¡ Remember FANBOYS: For, And, Nor, But, Or, Yet, So

Combining with subordinating conjunctions (because, if, when, although, unless, while, before, after):
Simple: He worked hard. He succeeded in SSC.
Combined: Because he worked hard, he succeeded in SSC.
Simple: She will attend Pohela Boishakh. She is invited.
Combined: She will attend Pohela Boishakh if she is invited.
ðŸ’¡ Tip: Use 'because' for reason, 'when' for time, 'if' for condition

Combining using relative pronouns (who, which, that):
Simple: The student wrote the essay. The student is from Dhaka.
Combined: The student who wrote the essay is from Dhaka.
Simple: This is the book. I read this book for SSC.
Combined: This is the book which I read for SSC.
ðŸ’¡ Use 'who' for people, 'which' for things, 'that' for both

Combining using participles (present or past participles):
Simple: He left home in Dhaka. He forgot his books.
Combined: Leaving home in Dhaka, he forgot his books.
Simple: The girl was dressed in traditional Bangladeshi clothes. She walked down the street.
Combined: Dressed in traditional Bangladeshi clothes, the girl walked down the street.

Combining using prepositional phrases:
Simple: We reached home. It was evening.
Combined: We reached home in the evening.
Simple: He solved the math problem. He had patience.
Combined: He solved the math problem with patience.
ðŸ’¡ Common prepositions: in, on, at, with, by, for, during

lessons.en:
Modifiers: Words or phrases that describe, limit, or qualify other words. Understanding modifiers is important for clear writing in SSC/HSC exams!
Types: Adjectives modify nouns (beautiful mango), Adverbs modify verbs/adjectives/adverbs (walks slowly), Prepositional phrases (in Dhaka), Participial phrases, Relative clauses.
ðŸ’¡ Modifier = Word that gives more information about another word

Misplaced Modifiers: A modifier placed too far from the word it describes, causing confusion.
Wrong: Running quickly, the tree seemed to move. (Tree is not running!)
Correct: Running quickly, the student dodged the tree.
Wrong: I bought a saree from my friend with a torn edge. (Friend doesn't have torn edge)
Correct: I bought a saree with a torn edge from my friend.
ðŸ’¡ Place the modifier CLOSE to the word it describes!

Dangling Modifiers: A modifier that doesn't clearly describe any word in the sentence. This is a common mistake!
Wrong: Finishing the homework, the television was turned on. (Television didn't finish homework)
Correct: Finishing the homework, she turned on the television.
Wrong: Broken into pieces, I couldn't repair the Bangladesh flag model. (I'm not broken)
Correct: Broken into pieces, the Bangladesh flag model couldn't be repaired.
ðŸ’¡ Make sure your modifier has a clear subject to describe!

Position of Modifiers:
Adjectives: Usually before nouns (beautiful girl) or after linking verbs (The girl is beautiful)
Adverbs: Can be at the beginning, middle, or end of a sentence
Prepositional phrases: Usually after the noun they modify
Participial phrases: Should be near the noun they describe
Relative clauses: Should immediately follow the noun they modify

Common Modifier Errors:
1. Squinting modifier: A modifier that could describe the word before or after it
Wrong: The girl who sang badly was praised. (Ambiguous)
Correct: The girl who sang very badly was still praised.
2. Adverb placement: Some adverbs change meaning based on position
Example: Only I saw the movie. / I only saw the movie. / I saw only the movie.

Correcting Modifier Problems:
1. Place the modifier close to the word it describes
2. Make sure the modifier has a clear word to describe
3. Ensure the subject of the main clause matches the implied subject of the modifier
4. Use commas to clarify relationships
Wrong: Walking home, it started to rain. â†’ Correct: As I was walking home, it started to rain.

lessons.en: ðŸŽ“ Welcome to HSC Grammar! This section covers university-level grammar for HSC exams and higher studies. Master these concepts for excellent results!

Conditional Sentences (Types 0, 1, 2, 3): Express real and unreal situations.
Type 0 (Universal Truth): If + present, present. Example: If you heat water to 100Â°C, it boils.
Type 1 (Real Future): If + present, will + verb. Example: If I study hard, I will pass HSC.
Type 2 (Unreal Present): If + past, would + verb. Example: If I were rich, I would travel Bangladesh.
Type 3 (Unreal Past): If + past perfect, would have + V3. Example: If I had studied, I would have passed.

Subjunctive Mood: Used for wishes, demands, suggestions, and unreal conditions.
Wishes: I wish I were in Cox's Bazar. (not 'was')
Demands: The teacher demands that he submit the assignment. (not 'submits')
Suggestions: It's important that she be present. (not 'is')
ðŸ’¡ After 'wish', use 'were' for all persons. After 'suggest/demand/require', use base form.

Inversion for Emphasis: Reverse subject and verb for dramatic effect or after negative words.
After 'Never': Never have I seen such beauty. (Not: I have never seen)
After 'Hardly': Hardly had the rain stopped when we left. (Not: The rain had hardly stopped)
After 'Only': Only then did I realize my mistake.
With 'So/Such': So beautiful was the Sundarbans that I cried.
ðŸ’¡ HSC Important: This makes your writing more sophisticated!

Parallel Structure: Keep similar items in lists in the same grammatical form.
Wrong: She likes reading, to write, and swimming.
Correct: She likes reading, writing, and swimming. (all gerunds)
Wrong: The HSC exam tests your grammar, vocabulary, and how you write.
Correct: The HSC exam tests your grammar, vocabulary, and writing skills.
ðŸ’¡ Use same forms: all nouns, all verbs, all adjectives - keep it parallel!

Ellipsis and Substitution: Avoid repetition by omitting or replacing words.
Ellipsis: I can speak English and my brother can too. (omit 'speak English')
Substitution: This book is interesting and so is that one. (one = book)
Example: Do you want to go to Dhaka University? I hope to. (omit 'go to Dhaka University')
ðŸ’¡ Makes your writing cleaner and more natural!

lessons.en: ðŸŽ“ Advanced Sentence Patterns: Master complex structures for HSC writing excellence! Understanding these patterns will make your compositions stand out and earn higher marks.

Compound-Complex Sentences: Combine multiple independent and dependent clauses.
Structure: Independent clause + Independent clause + Dependent clause
Example: The HSC exam is challenging, but students who prepare well will succeed because they have strong foundations.
ðŸ’¡ Use these to show sophisticated thinking in your essays!

Noun Clauses: A clause that functions as a noun (subject, object, or complement).
As Subject: What you study determines your HSC results.
As Object: I know that Dhaka University is prestigious.
With Question Words: She asked where the library was.
After 'that': The fact that he passed amazed everyone.
ðŸ’¡ Common introducers: that, what, whether, if, who, when, where, why, how

Adjective Clauses (Relative Clauses): Describe nouns with who, which, that, whose, where, when.
Defining: The student who studies hard succeeds. (essential information)
Non-defining: My brother, who lives in Chittagong, is a doctor. (extra info, use commas)
With 'whose': The teacher whose class I attend is excellent.
With 'where': Dhaka, where I was born, is the capital.
ðŸ’¡ HSC tip: Non-defining clauses add sophistication to your writing!

Adverb Clauses: Show time, reason, condition, contrast, purpose, or result.
Time: When the bell rings, class begins. / After I finish HSC, I will attend university.
Reason: Because he studied diligently, he scored A+.
Condition: If you work hard, you will succeed.
Contrast: Although the exam was difficult, students performed well.
Purpose: She studies hard so that she can get into medical college.
ðŸ’¡ Position: Can be at beginning (use comma) or end (no comma needed)

Reduced Clauses: Shorten clauses by removing subject and changing verb to participle.
Full: While I was studying for HSC, I learned many things.
Reduced: While studying for HSC, I learned many things.
Full: The student who was selected for the debate won.
Reduced: The student selected for the debate won.
ðŸ’¡ Makes writing more concise and academic!

Appositives & Absolute Phrases:
Appositive: A noun phrase that renames another noun.
Example: Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh, is a bustling city.
Example: My friend Rahim, an excellent student, won the scholarship.
Absolute Phrase: Adds extra information to the whole sentence.
Example: The exam being over, students celebrated joyfully.
Example: His homework completed, Karim went to play cricket.
ðŸ’¡ These add variety and sophistication to HSC essays!

Embedded Questions & Indirect Speech Patterns:
Direct Question: Where is the Sundarbans?
Embedded: I wonder where the Sundarbans is. (No question mark, different word order)
Direct: How can I improve my English?
Embedded: I don't know how I can improve my English.
ðŸ’¡ Use embedded questions in formal writing for HSC exams!

lessons.en: ðŸŽ“ Articles & Determiners: Master the subtle art of using 'a', 'an', 'the', and zero article for HSC excellence! These small words make big differences in meaning.

Zero Article (No Article): Used with plural countable nouns and uncountable nouns when speaking generally.
General Truth: Students need education. (all students, not specific)
Countries: Bangladesh is beautiful. (but: The United Kingdom)
Meals: I eat breakfast at 7 AM. (but: The breakfast was delicious - specific)
Subjects: She studies mathematics. (but: The mathematics in HSC is challenging)
ðŸ’¡ HSC Tip: Zero article = general meaning!

Definite Article 'The': Used when both speaker and listener know which specific thing is meant.
Unique Things: The sun, the moon, the Padma Bridge, the Sundarbans
Previously Mentioned: I saw a student. The student was from Dhaka.
Superlatives: The best HSC student, the most difficult exam
Ordinals: The first day, the second chance
ðŸ’¡ Use 'the' when the noun is specific and identifiable!

Indefinite Articles 'A/An': Used with singular countable nouns when not specific.
First Mention: I need a pen. (any pen, not specific)
Profession: She is a teacher. He wants to be an engineer.
One: A hundred students, an hour ago
'A' before consonant sounds: a university (sounds like 'yu')
'An' before vowel sounds: an hour (silent 'h')
ðŸ’¡ Use when introducing something new or non-specific!

Specific vs. General Reference:
General: Books are important. (all books)
Specific: The books on my desk are HSC materials. (particular books)
General: Water is essential. (all water)
Specific: The water in this bottle is cold. (particular water)
ðŸ’¡ Think: Am I talking about ALL or SPECIFIC?

Articles with Proper Nouns:
No Article: Bangladesh, Dhaka, Mount Everest, Dhaka University
With 'The': The Bay of Bengal, The Himalayas, The United States, The Padma Bridge
Newspapers: The Daily Star, The New York Times
Hotels/Buildings: The Sheraton, The Empire State Building
ðŸ’¡ Rivers, oceans, mountain ranges use 'the'!

Common Determiners: All, both, each, every, either, neither, some, any, no, several, few, little, many, much.
All students, both exams, each question, every day
Some help, any doubt, no problem, several books
Few students (countable), Little time (uncountable)
Many questions (countable), Much effort (uncountable)
ðŸ’¡ Countable vs. Uncountable changes the determiner!

Fixed Expressions:
With Article: in the morning, in the afternoon, go to the cinema, play the piano
Without Article: at night, at home, go to school/college/university, play cricket/football
Special Cases: go to bed (sleep) vs. sit on the bed (furniture)
ðŸ’¡ Learn fixed expressions by heart for HSC!

lessons.en: ðŸŽ“ Advanced Prepositions: Master complex prepositional patterns for HSC! Prepositions show relationships between words and are crucial for academic writing.

Phrasal Prepositions (Multi-word): Common patterns using 2-3 words acting as one preposition.
Apart from, According to, Because of, Due to, In spite of
With regard to, In addition to, On behalf of, By means of
Example: Apart from English, I study mathematics.
In spite of the rain, the HSC exam continued.
ðŸ’¡ HSC Tip: Learn these as fixed phrases!

Prepositions of Time (Complex):
By (deadline): Finish by Friday. (before Friday ends)
Within (duration): Reply within a week. (anytime in 7 days)
Throughout (entire period): Study throughout the year.
During (specific time): During the HSC exam season.
For (duration): I studied for three hours.
Since (starting point): Since 2020, I've been preparing.
ðŸ’¡ 'By' = deadline, 'Within' = anytime before deadline!

Prepositions of Cause and Reason:
Because of / Due to / Owing to (+ noun): The exam was postponed because of rain.
On account of: On account of illness, she missed the test.
Thanks to: Thanks to hard work, I passed.
For: Famous for hospitality (Bangladesh is famous for its hospitality).
ðŸ’¡ 'Because of' and 'due to' are interchangeable!

Prepositions with Adjectives:
Afraid of, Angry with/at, Good at, Bad at, Famous for
Interested in, Fond of, Proud of, Capable of, Aware of
Similar to, Different from, Familiar with, Responsible for
Example: Bangladeshi students are good at mathematics.
Dhaka is famous for its rich history.
ðŸ’¡ Learn adjective + preposition combinations!

Prepositions with Verbs:
Dependon, Consist of, Believe in, Succeed in, Participate in
Apologize for, Thank for, Blame for, Search for, Care for
Look at/for/after, Deal with, Agree with/to, Differ from
Example: Success depends on hard work.
I apologized for being late to the HSC exam.
ðŸ’¡ Fixed verb + preposition patterns!

Complex Prepositional Phrases:
In accordance with: Follow the rules in accordance with HSC guidelines.
With respect to / With reference to: With respect to your application...
In terms of: In terms of difficulty, chemistry is challenging.
For the purpose of: Study for the purpose of gaining knowledge.
In the course of: In the course of my studies...
ðŸ’¡ Use these for formal/academic writing!

Common Preposition Errors:
âŒ Discuss about â†’ âœ… Discuss (no preposition)
âŒ Marry with â†’ âœ… Marry (no preposition)
âŒ Reach at â†’ âœ… Reach (no preposition)
âŒ Different than â†’ âœ… Different from
âŒ Comprised of â†’ âœ… Composed of / Comprises
âŒ Explain about â†’ âœ… Explain (no preposition)
ðŸ’¡ Some verbs don't need prepositions!

Prepositions of Place (Advanced):
Among (more than two): Among all students, she is the best.
Between (two): Between you and me, the exam was easy.
Beside (next to): Sit beside me.
Besides (in addition to): Besides English, I study science.
Beneath / Underneath: Beneath the surface, the problem is serious.
ðŸ’¡ Among = 3+, Between = 2!

lessons.en: ðŸŽ“ Academic Punctuation: Master advanced punctuation for HSC essays and formal writing! Proper punctuation makes your writing clear and professional.

Semicolons (;): Used to connect closely related independent clauses without a conjunction.
Two Related Ideas: I love Dhaka; it's my hometown.
With Conjunctive Adverbs: She studied hard; therefore, she passed.
Complex Lists: Invited: Karim, Dhaka; Rina, Chittagong; Sohel, Sylhet.
âŒ Wrong: I study hard; because I want to succeed. (semicolon before 'because')
âœ… Right: I study hard because I want to succeed.
ðŸ’¡ HSC Tip: Use semicolons for sophisticated writing!

Colons (:): Used to introduce lists, explanations, or examples.
Lists: You need three things: a pen, paper, and determination.
Explanation: She has one goal: to pass HSC with flying colors.
Quotations: The teacher said: "Work hard for success."
Time: 3:30 PM, Ratio: 2:1
âŒ Wrong: The subjects are: Physics, Chemistry, Biology. (colon after 'are')
âœ… Right: The subjects are Physics, Chemistry, and Biology.
ðŸ’¡ Don't use colon right after a verb!

Dashes (â€”): Em dash for emphasis, parenthetical information, or sudden breaks.
Emphasis: HSC preparationâ€”the most crucial yearâ€”requires dedication.
Interruption: The examâ€”oh no, I forgot my penâ€”was about to start.
Explanation: Three cities in Bangladeshâ€”Dhaka, Chittagong, Sylhetâ€”are major hubs.
Vs. Hyphen (-): Short, connects words (well-known, twenty-one)
ðŸ’¡ Em dash (â€”) is longer than hyphen (-)!

Parentheses () vs. Brackets []:
Parentheses: Add extra information (The Padma Bridge (completed in 2022) connects regions).
Optional Info: She scored well in all subjects (especially mathematics).
Brackets: Editorial additions in quotes "He [the Prime Minister] announced..."
Within Parentheses: (Bangladesh [formerly East Pakistan] became independent in 1971)
ðŸ’¡ Parentheses for your additions, brackets for clarification in quotes!

Quotation Marks (" ") and Apostrophes ('):
Direct Speech: She said, "I will study hard for HSC."
Quotes: According to Shakespeare, "To be or not to be."
Titles: "The Daily Star" (newspaper), "Education in Bangladesh" (article)
Apostrophes: Possession (Karim's book), Contractions (don't, it's)
âŒ Its' (wrong) â†’ âœ… Its (possession) or It's (it is)
ðŸ’¡ Punctuation inside quotes in American English!

Ellipsis (...): Shows omission in quotations or trailing thoughts.
Omitted Text: "The beginning...and the end." (middle removed)
Pause/Trailing: I wonder...will I pass the HSC?
Three Dots: Always use three dots (...), not two or four.
With Period: If ending a sentence, use four (....) but modern style uses three.
ðŸ’¡ Use sparingly in academic writing!

Comma Usage (Advanced):
Oxford Comma: I study physics, chemistry, and biology. (comma before 'and')
Non-Essential Info: My teacher, who is from Dhaka, is excellent. (extra info)
Essential Info: Students who work hard succeed. (no commas, essential)
Conjunctive Adverbs: She studied; however, she didn't pass.
Introductory Elements: After finishing the exam, I felt relieved.
ðŸ’¡ Oxford comma prevents ambiguity!

Capitalization Rules:
Start of Sentence: The exam begins tomorrow.
Proper Nouns: Bangladesh, Dhaka, Padma Bridge, October
Titles: Dr. Karim, Prime Minister, President
Title Case: "The Importance of Education in Bangladesh" (capitalize major words)
Days/Months: Monday, January (but seasons: winter, summer)
ðŸ’¡ Don't capitalize subjects unless proper names: mathematics, but English!

lessons.en: ðŸŽ“ Word Order & Emphasis: Master advanced sentence structures for HSC! Learn to emphasize important information using special word order patterns.

Cleft Sentences with 'It is...that/who': Used to emphasize a particular part of a sentence.
Normal: Karim won the prize.
Emphasis on Subject: It was Karim who won the prize.
Emphasis on Object: It was the prize that Karim won.
Emphasis on Time: It was yesterday that Karim won the prize.
ðŸ’¡ HSC Tip: Use 'who' for people, 'that' for things!

Cleft Sentences with 'What...is/was': Emphasizes actions or objects.
Normal: She needs confidence.
Emphasis: What she needs is confidence.
Normal: He said something strange.
Emphasis: What he said was strange.
Normal: I want success in HSC.
Emphasis: What I want is success in HSC.
ðŸ’¡ 'What' clauses emphasize the noun/action!

Fronting (Moving to Front): Moving important information to the beginning for emphasis.
Normal: She achieved success through hard work.
Fronting: Through hard work, she achieved success.
Normal: I have never seen such dedication.
Fronting: Never have I seen such dedication. (with inversion)
ðŸ’¡ Fronting draws attention to the moved element!

Inversion for Emphasis: Changing subject-verb order after negative or limiting adverbs.
Never: Never have I seen such a beautiful place. (Not: Never I have seen)
Rarely: Rarely does she miss class.
Seldom: Seldom do we get such opportunities.
Not only: Not only did he pass, but he also got the highest marks.
Hardly/Scarcely: Hardly had the exam started when the power went out.
ðŸ’¡ Negative adverbs at the start require inversion!

Passive Voice for Emphasis: Emphasizes the action or object, de-emphasizes the agent.
Active: The government built the Padma Bridge.
Passive (Emphasis on Bridge): The Padma Bridge was built by the government.
Passive (Agent omitted): The Padma Bridge was built in 2022.
When to Use: Focus on action/object, agent unknown or obvious
ðŸ’¡ Passive = object becomes more important!

Double Emphasis (It is...that + Cleft): Combining techniques for maximum emphasis.
Very Strong Emphasis: It was because of hard work that she succeeded.
Normal: She succeeded because of hard work.
Double Cleft: What it was that helped her was hard work.
ðŸ’¡ Use sparingly in academic writing!

'There' Structures: Emphasizes existence or presence.
Normal: Many students are in the library.
Emphasis: There are many students in the library.
Normal: A problem exists with the system.
Emphasis: There is a problem with the system.
ðŸ’¡ 'There' + be introduces new information!

End-Weight (Heavy Information Last): Place complex/long information at the end.
âŒ Awkward: That you passed the HSC exam pleases me.
âœ… Better: It pleases me that you passed the HSC exam.
âŒ Awkward: To study hard for HSC is necessary.
âœ… Better: It is necessary to study hard for HSC.
ðŸ’¡ Short before long = natural rhythm!

lessons.en: ðŸŽ“ Determiners & Quantifiers: Master the words that specify quantity and definiteness for HSC! These small words control the meaning of nouns.

Each vs. Every: Both mean 'all individual items', but with subtle differences.
Each: Emphasizes individual items separately (2 or more)
- Each student has a book. (thinking of students individually)
- Each of the students... (followed by 'of')
Every: Emphasizes the group as a whole (3 or more)
- Every student must attend. (all students, no exceptions)
- âŒ Every of the students (can't use 'of' with 'every')
ðŸ’¡ Each = individual focus, Every = group focus!

Either vs. Neither (for two items):
Either: One or the other (of two), positive meaning
- Either answer is correct. (this one OR that one)
- Either of the books... (followed by 'of')
Neither: Not one and not the other (of two), negative
- Neither answer is correct. (not this one AND not that one)
- Neither of the students passed. (both failed)
ðŸ’¡ Either/Neither are only for TWO items!

Much vs. Many, Few vs. Little:
Countable Nouns (can count): Many, few, a few
- Many students, few opportunities, a few books
- How many questions? (asking about countable)
Uncountable Nouns (can't count): Much, little, a little
- Much time, little money, a little water
- How much effort? (asking about uncountable)
ðŸ’¡ 'Few' = negative (almost none), 'A few' = positive (some)!

'A few' vs. 'Few', 'A little' vs. 'Little':
A few (countable): Some, a small number (positive)
- I have a few friends in Dhaka. (some friends, positive)
Few (countable): Almost none, not enough (negative)
- Few students passed the test. (very few, disappointing)
A little (uncountable): Some, a small amount (positive)
- I have a little time to help you. (some time, positive)
Little (uncountable): Almost none, not enough (negative)
- There is little hope of success. (very little, pessimistic)
ðŸ’¡ 'A' makes it positive!

All, Both, Half:
All: 100% of three or more items
- All students, all of the students, all the students
Both: 100% of exactly two items
- Both exams, both of the exams, both the exams
Half: 50% of any number
- Half the class, half of the students
ðŸ’¡ All = 3+, Both = exactly 2!

Some vs. Any:
Some: Used in positive statements and offers/requests
- I have some books. (positive statement)
- Would you like some tea? (offer)
- Can I have some help? (polite request)
Any: Used in negative statements and questions
- I don't have any money. (negative)
- Do you have any questions? (question)
- Use in conditions: If you have any problems, call me.
ðŸ’¡ 'Some' in questions = expecting 'yes' answer!

No, None, Neither:
No + noun: Not any, zero
- No student failed. (zero students failed)
- I have no money. (I don't have any money)
None (alone): Not one, zero (replaces noun)
- How many failed? None. (zero people)
- None of the students failed.
Neither (for two): Not one and not the other
- Neither student passed. (both failed)
ðŸ’¡ 'No' needs a noun, 'None' stands alone!

Several, Numerous, Plenty of:
Several: More than two but not many (3-7 approximately)
- Several students asked questions. (a few, countable only)
Numerous: Many, a large number (formal)
- Numerous studies show... (many studies, formal writing)
Plenty of: More than enough (countable and uncountable)
- Plenty of time, plenty of students
ðŸ’¡ 'Several' is informal, 'Numerous' is formal!

lessons.en: ðŸŽ“ Advanced Reported Speech: Master the art of reporting what others said for HSC! Learn complex reporting patterns beyond basic rules.

Advanced Reporting Verbs: Use specific verbs to show how something was said.
Say/Tell: Basic reporting
- She said (that) she was tired. / She told me (that) she was tired.
Other Verbs: Explain, mention, complain, suggest, promise, warn, remind, advise
- He suggested (that) I study harder. (suggestion)
- She warned me not to be late. (warning)
- They promised to help. (promise)
ðŸ’¡ Different verbs show different intentions!

Mixed Tenses in Reported Speech: When the reporting verb is present or the statement is still true.
Present Reporting Verb: No tense change needed
- She says she is tired. (says = present, so 'is' stays)
- He tells me he likes Dhaka. (tells = present)
Universal Truth: No tense change
- The teacher said, "The sun rises in the east."
- The teacher said (that) the sun rises in the east. (still true)
ðŸ’¡ Universal truths keep present tense!

Reporting Questions (Advanced Patterns):
Yes/No Questions: Use if/whether
- "Do you like Dhaka?" â†’ He asked if/whether I liked Dhaka.
Wh- Questions: Use the question word
- "Where do you live?" â†’ She asked where I lived.
Indirect Questions: Polite questions already in statement form
- "Could you tell me what time it is?" â†’ He asked what time it was.
ðŸ’¡ No question mark in reported questions!

Reporting Commands and Requests:
Commands: tell/order + someone + (not) to + verb
- "Study hard!" â†’ The teacher told us to study hard.
- "Don't be late!" â†’ She warned us not to be late.
Requests: ask + someone + (not) to + verb
- "Please help me." â†’ He asked me to help him.
- "Could you open the door?" â†’ She asked me to open the door.
ðŸ’¡ Use 'to + infinitive' for commands/requests!

Reporting with Modal Verbs (Advanced):
Shifting Modals:
- Will â†’ would: "I will come" â†’ He said he would come.
- Can â†’ could: "I can do it" â†’ She said she could do it.
- May â†’ might: "It may rain" â†’ He said it might rain.
No Change for: would, could, should, might, ought to, used to
- "I would like tea" â†’ He said he would like tea.
ðŸ’¡ Some modals don't change in reported speech!

Reporting Suggestions and Advice:
Suggest: suggest + that + subject + (should) + verb OR suggest + -ing
- "Let's go to Dhaka." â†’ He suggested (that) we go/should go to Dhaka.
- He suggested going to Dhaka.
Advise/Recommend: advise/recommend + (that) + subject + (should) + verb
- "You should study more." â†’ She advised (that) I study/should study more.
ðŸ’¡ 'Should' is often optional in these patterns!

Reporting with Special Verbs:
Admit, Deny: admit/deny + -ing
- "Yes, I broke the rule." â†’ He admitted breaking the rule.
- "I didn't cheat." â†’ She denied cheating on the exam.
Apologize, Blame: apologize for / blame someone for + -ing
- "Sorry for being late." â†’ He apologized for being late.
- "You caused the problem." â†’ He blamed me for causing the problem.
ðŸ’¡ These verbs use gerund (-ing form)!

Complex Reported Speech - Mixed Structures:
Reporting Long Conversations: Use multiple clauses
- She explained that she had been studying for hours and that she needed rest.
Reporting with Reasons: Include explanatory clauses
- He said he couldn't come because he was busy with HSC preparation.
Reporting Consequences: Use result clauses
- She mentioned that if she studied hard, she would pass.
ðŸ’¡ Link multiple ideas with 'that', 'and', 'because'!

lessons.en: ðŸŽ“ Advanced Modal Verbs: Master modal verbs for HSC success! Modals express possibility, necessity, ability, permission, and moreâ€”crucial for academic writing.

Modals of Deduction (Certainty/Possibility):
Must (strong certainty, 90-95%): She must be at home. (I'm almost certain)
Can't/Couldn't (impossibility): He can't be tired. (impossible)
May/Might/Could (possibility, 20-50%): It may rain. (maybe/possibly)
Should/Ought to (expectation, 70-80%): The train should arrive soon. (I expect)
ðŸ’¡ HSC Tip: 'Must' = very certain, 'May/Might' = unsure!

Past Modals for Deduction (Past Events):
Must have + past participle: He must have studied hard. (I'm certain he studied)
Can't have + past participle: She can't have forgotten. (impossible to forget)
May/Might have + past participle: They might have missed the bus. (possibly missed)
Should have + past participle: You should have studied more. (expectation/advice for past)
ðŸ’¡ Use 'have + past participle' for past deductions!

Modals of Obligation and Necessity:
Must (strong obligation): Students must submit assignments. (required, no choice)
Have to (external necessity): I have to attend the HSC exam. (external requirement)
Should/Ought to (advice/mild obligation): You should study daily. (good idea, recommended)
Need to (necessity): We need to prepare better. (necessary action)
Must vs. Have to: Must = speaker's opinion, Have to = external rule
ðŸ’¡ 'Must' for rules you make, 'Have to' for external rules!

Modals of No Obligation (Not Necessary):
Don't have to/Don't need to (not necessary): You don't have to come. (optional)
Needn't (British, same as don't have to): You needn't worry. (no need to worry)
Mustn't (prohibition, DO NOT): You mustn't cheat in exams. (forbidden, prohibited)
âš ï¸ Important: Mustn't â‰  Don't have to!
ðŸ’¡ 'Mustn't' = forbidden, 'Don't have to' = optional!

Modals of Ability:
Can (present ability): She can speak English fluently.
Could (past ability or polite): I could swim when I was young. / Could you help me?
Be able to (alternative to can): She is able to solve complex problems.
Managed to (succeeded in difficult situation): Despite difficulties, he managed to pass.
ðŸ’¡ Use 'managed to' for difficult achievements!

Modals of Permission and Prohibition:
Can/May (permission): You can/may leave now. (I allow you)
Could/Might (polite permission): Could I use your pen? (very polite)
Must/Mustn't (strong permission/prohibition): You must finish this. / You mustn't copy.
Be allowed to: Students are allowed to use calculators in physics.
ðŸ’¡ 'May' and 'Could' are more polite than 'Can'!

Would, Could, Should for Advice and Suggestions:
Should (advice): You should practice more for the HSC exam.
Could (suggestion): You could try studying in the morning. (possible option)
Would (polite suggestion/offer): Would you like some help? / I would recommend this book.
Ought to (similar to should, formal): You ought to revise regularly.
ðŸ’¡ 'Should' = advice, 'Could' = possible option!

Modal Perfect (Past Criticism/Regret):
Should have (didn't do, regret): I should have studied harder. (regret not studying)
Shouldn't have (did, regret): I shouldn't have wasted time. (regret wasting)

examples.en:
Must (Certainty): She must be a good student; she always gets excellent marks in HSC.
(I'm almost certain she's good)

Can't (Impossibility): He can't be from Dhaka; he doesn't know where the Padma Bridge is.
(Impossible that he's from Dhaka)

May/Might (Possibility): It might rain tomorrow, so take an umbrella to school.
(Possibly will rain, uncertain)

Must have (Past Certainty): She must have studied all night; she looks very tired today.
(I'm certain she studied all night)

Should have (Past Advice): You should have started preparing for HSC earlier.
(Regret/criticism for not starting earlier)

Must (Obligation): All HSC candidates must register before the deadline.
(Required, no choice)

Don't have to (No Obligation): You don't have to attend the optional class tomorrow.
(Not required, optional)

Could you (Polite Request): Could you please explain this grammar rule again?
(Very polite request)
